Below is a list of this week's Tyne & Wear community events written by you. To get your event included, simply fill out the form at www.chroniclelive.co.uk/yourevents How to manage your money course in Gateshead 
The Gateshead Housing Company is helping residents to manage the financial pressure of Christmas, with a free ‘How to manage your money’ course at Gateshead Clubhouse, Worcester Green, NE8 1NH on Thursday 25 January, from 10am to 1pm. 
Involvement and diversity lead Helen Watson said: “This is a great way for people to find out more about how to budget, especially after the Christmas period. 
“We know how the current economic climate has put a strain on residents’ finances so this course will advise on prioritising bills, and what to do if you are in rent arrears. 
“Attendees can also find out about credit and borrowing, saving on energy bills, and the help available from the housing company. 
“Our priority as a landlord is to help our tenants to sustain their tenancy and this course will help address some of the other pressures that tenants can face.” 
The course is part of the company’s Moving Forward training programme, and is open to anyone who lives in Gateshead. Support to attend is available, including transport and interpreters.Residents can find out more about the Moving Forward training programme and other ways to get involved by emailing involve@gatesheadhousing.co.uk or by calling 0191 433 5357. Rugby club for women across the North East 
What: Inner Warrior Camp 
When: Thursday 25th January 2018 at 6-7pm girls (11-17 years) and 7-8pm social ladies. 
Where: Darlington Mowden Park Rugby Club 
More information: “As women’s rugby is become increasingly popular, assisted by the success of the England team, we’d love to attract as many people as possible to this event. Our team members are not only Darlington-based as some travel in the North East for training! 
“We play both touch & contact rugby, so come down & give it a try! We’re a friendly & sociable group, & we’d love as many people to come down as possible. No experience required and those wishing to return back to rugby area also welcome! Get fit & make new friends.”

Worldwide collaborative textile arts venture in Durham 
Community groups, individuals, schools and artists have been working together for more than a year in a worldwide collaborative textile arts venture which will be displayed for the first time at Durham Cathedral in 2018 from January 25-29 to coincide with World Holocaust Day. 
Coxhoe Quilt Group is among those who have taken part. 
The 70273 project, which commemorates the people with disabilities killed during “Aktion T4” by the Nazi regime in Germany during 1940-1941, was begun by Jeanne Hewell-Chambers from America, and Jeanne and her husband will come to Britain prior to the exhibition to meet some of the people who have played a major part in bringing the project to the North-East. 
The project gets its name from the 70,273 disabled men, women and children recorded as being killed under the Nazi regime. Three doctors inspected the medical records of each person and if two doctors marked a cross on the records, the person was deemed to be “unworthy of life” and an “economic burden”. People were then killed in a variety of ways and were often murdered within hours. 
To commemorate each individual killed in this brutal manner, Jeanne has invited people worldwide to create a single white textile square with two red crosses, to reflect the doctors’ crosses on the medical records. These are being joined together to make quilts which will then tour worldwide to raise awareness and as a learning tool. To date, almost one-third of the total has been achieved. Concert at Durham Miners’ Hall 
What: Richard Dawson and Onsind. With a clutch of critically acclaimed albums under his belt, the performance by Richard in the magnificent Council Chamber, known as ‘The Pitman’s Parliament’, marks a new chapter in terms of cultural activity in this magnificent Grade-II listed building. Support comes from Durham band Onsind. Tickets are £10. 
When: Friday February 2 at 7.30pm. 
Where: Durham Miners Hall, Redhills, Durham City, DH1 4BE. Community event success in Kenton Staff and committee of Kenton Park Community Association plus local volunteers dressed as elves ready for Santa's arrival (Image: UGC TNE) 
Kenton Park Sports Centre duty manager Fran Richardson said: “Our fantastic community Christmas event was held on Thursday, December 14, called Kenton’s Christmas Cracker. 
“The event took place at Kenton Park Sports Centre where over 80 local families enjoyed various activities including personalised Santa’s Grotto visits, live reindeer, funfair rides, inflatables and festive arts & crafts. 
“This event was kindly supported by local businessman Rob Armstrong.” Public lecture at Newcastle University 
What: Public lecture with Danny Dorling called The Global Race. 
Danny will discuss Brexit, racism, equality, immigration, Europe, equality, trust and understanding. The event aims to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr’s visit to Newcastle University. 
When: 6.30pm, January 29. 
Where: Herschel Building, Newcastle University , NE1 7RU. 
Organised by: Newcastle Geography Society.
